title: $A weaker after mixed jobs figures
text:
Thu, Aug 6, 2015, 10:27 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A weaker after mixed jobs figures AAP – 4 hours ago Print 
The Australian dollar is lower after a mixed reaction to July employment figures. 
At 1700 AEST on Thursday, the local unit was trading at 73.30 US cents, down from 73.49 cents on Wednesday. 
The currency briefly shot up to 73.88 US cents after figures showed unemployment unexpectedly jumped to a six-month high of 6.3 per cent. 
It quickly retraced though, as the data also showed the number of people in the workforce or looking for work surged to a two year high, and the total number of people with jobs rose 38,500 in the month. 
ThinkForex senior markets analyst Matt Simpson said mixed figures tend to have a mixed effect on the currency. 
"With the employment change being too volatile to establish meaningful trends it is always the unemployment rate which attracts the attention," he said. 
"A mixed data set tends to result in mixed price action." 
With commodity prices falling and the US dollar strengthening on the back of expectations of a September US interest rate hike, the Australian dollar is likely to be under pressure in the coming weeks, Mr Simpson said. 
US non farm payrolls employment figures, out on Friday night, will be a key focus for financial markets and a crucial indicator for what the Fed will do, he said. 
"If strong US employment occurs traders will likely take that as confirmation of a September rate hike, pushing the greenback up further and weighing on the Australian dollar," he said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.50 Japanese yen, up from Wednesday's close of 91.41 yen, and at 67.16 euro cents, down from 67.59 euro cents. 
Meanwhile, the bond market was slightly weaker. 
Bond futures prices fell in overnight trade after US non-manufacturing activity rose to a 10 year high in July and the UK services sector posted a solid gain in the same month. 
Australian bond futures moved in line with US Treasuries in the early hours of Thursday morning but levelled off during the day as traders wait for key economy events. 
On Thursday night, the Bank of England will finish its policy meeting and could flag an interest rate in the near future. 
On Friday, the Reserve Bank of Australia will release its latest economic forecasts in its Statement on Monetary Policy. 
At 1630 AEST on Thursday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.140 (implying a yield of 2.860 per cent), down from 97.160 (2.840 per cent) on Wednesday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.020 (1.980 per cent), level with the previous local close. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Super rate of 9.5pc 'simply too low': FSC AAP
